abstract: Scientists led by Dr Huahua Xiao at the University of Maryland have created fire whirls, colloquially known as firenadoes, which burn hotter than many other fires and could be useful for number of applications, including oil spill cleanup.

headline.print_headline: Sciencetake: An Effort to Put a Blue, Whirling Vortex of Fire to Good Use
headline.main: New Form of Fire, Inspired by Bourbon, Might Help With Oil Spills

keywords.value: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
keywords.name: organizations

snippet: Scientists turned a fire whirl, sometimes called a firenado, into a new form — a blue whirl — that burns clean and soot-free....
lead_paragraph: Scientists turned a fire whirl, sometimes called a firenado, into a new form — a blue whirl — that burns clean and soot-free.
